sources.title: I See A Dark Stranger
sources.description: “Highly entertaining” “Forgotten masterpiece” “Superior” “Casts a spell” “Strange and delightful” “Deborah Kerr = outstanding” (IMDB reviews quotes). A naive Irish lass (Kerr) who was raised on blood-curdling tales of the Republican Army hates all things English and Cromwell in particular. This leads to her getting caught up in a Nazi plot in this fast-paced and suspenseful spy thriller that doesn’t entirely neglect comedy. Trevor Howard costars at the head of a superb cast of Irish and English character actors. An outstanding production partially filmed in County Wexford and Dublin, Ireland and on the Isle of Man. Highly recommended. IMDB rating 7.1. Directed by Frank Launder. Released in 1946. Complete print. AKA “The Adventuress”

sources.title: I See a Dark Stranger
sources.description: Title: I See a Dark Stranger Summary: A young Irish woman hates England so much she becomes a Nazi spy. Directed by: Frank Launder Actors: Deborah Kerr, Trevor Howard, Raymond Huntley Production Company: Individual Pictures Release Date: 5 August 1946 (UK) Aspect Ratio: 1.37 : 1 Determined, independent Bridie Quilty comes of age in 1944 Ireland thinking all Englishmen are devils. Her desire to join the IRA meets no encouragement, but a German spy finds her easy to recruit. We next find her working in a pub near a British military prison, using her sex appeal in the service of the enemy. But chance puts a really vital secret into her hands, leading to a chase involving Bridie, a British officer who's fallen for her, a German agent unknown to them both, and the police...paralleled by Bridie's own internal conflicts.
